Award.AwardTitle: RET Site: Physically and Biologically Inspired Computational Models and Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award establishes a new Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) Site at Notre Dame University. The site focuses on engaging local high school teachers in summer research projects that explore computational models inspired by physical and biological systems. The RET Site will develop a strong partnership between Notre Dame and schools in the greater South Bend area, including public, private, and parochial schools. The site will recruit cohorts of high school teachers in the areas of Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) who will work on compelling research projects with faculty mentors and research teams in the summer and then will implement related inquiry-based learning modules and activities in their classrooms during the academic year. The interdisciplinary nature of the research theme will provide a fertile ground for developing creative and appealing high school lessons and teaching activities in biology, physics, math, and other engineering disciplines that align with state and national curricular standards.

RET Site teachers will attend a 7-week summer institute to participate in cutting-edge research projects with mentoring from engineering faculty who lead current research programs in the three areas of emphasis. The first area includes deep learning algorithms that solve problems such as language understanding and a behavior prediction most commonly using deep convolutional neural networks. These data-hungry and computationally intensive methods tend to produce models that are far more accurate than their conventional counterparts. The second thread involves non-Boolean/non-von Neumann neuromorphic hardware that processes data in an analog fashion. Systems that function like this could be inspired by the human retina which operates in a continuous fashion and processes continuous input flows with real spatial-temporal dynamics. The third thread encompasses computation models that are directly inspired by physics. This includes areas such as optically inspired computing models involving elements such as spin waves, magnetic lenses, and coupled oscillators to process information. These projects will provide true in-depth learning about computation, waves, and optics which are fundamental to the high school physics curriculum. Working with PIs and faculty mentors, teachers will develop innovative, standards-compliant curriculum modules and participate in a number of professional development activities. The teacher-created modules and lessons will be disseminated local through a RET handbook and on the Notre Dame RET website as well as at the annual workshop and disseminated through TeachEngineering.org, a nationally recognized repository for searchable, standards-based engineering curricula. Extensive follow-up activities are planned throughout the academic year to ensure the translation of lab experiences into classroom practice, and to foster and strengthen long-term partnership between engineering faculty and the local school districts. A third-party professional program evaluator will track and evaluate the program and provide feedback for improvement.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of the NSF RET site was on emerging computing models and algorithms that could lead to improvements in application-level performance that historically were enabled by technology scaling alone. During our initial submission, there was growing interest in biologically and physically inspired models that offered new ways to process information and/or that might be capable of performing similar computational tasks with much less energy. These trends/interests continue.

Projects targeted hardware/models that (i) are inspired by biological systems (with an emphasis on CNNs for deep learning), (ii) analog architectures inspired by the retina that can be more easily realized with emerging technologies, and (iii) that exploit the evolution of a physical system to solve a problem. 

Participants were actively involved in meaningful research projects across STEM disciplines, and the site readily adopted the best practices espoused in the call for proposals – i.e., “Teachers and/or community college faculty must be active participants and not just observers. Their research needs to have clear objectives and research questions.”

As one example, a teacher participant wanted to enhance physics labs that addressed topics such as current, voltage, resistance, and capacitance. Transistors (the subject of Moore’s Law scaling) are effectively voltage-controlled current switches and are a natural vehicle for discussing physics concepts at an application level. The teacher envisioned activities where Raspberry Pi chips running different workloads could be observed via infrared cameras. For more computationally intensive tasks, there are more transistor switching events (capacitance charging and discharging), there is additional data transfer (Joule heating via on-chip metal interconnect), etc., and a chip’s thermal signature changes.

The PIs crafted a project where a teacher would develop a machine learning (ML) model to characterize test results from cards being developed by an ND chemistry professor that can detect the presence or absence of various drugs – i.e., by a law enforcement office in the field. A card (referred to as an idPAD) is a chemical color test that responds to different functional groups of illicit drugs (e.g., cocaine, heroin, methamphetamine, and crack cocaine).  Based on the color produced in various lanes (color barcode), a specific drug or combination of drugs can be identified. At present, image recognition requires officer training. A project goal is to have a mobile device that can be used to detect the presence (or absence) of a specific drug based on the signature of the idPAD. The teacher used knowledge/skills that were developed during initial RET site activities (e.g., Keras tutorials, etc.) to develop a CNN model to address this classification problem. The teacher experimented with different network parameters to improve classification accuracy, and the model achieved inference accuracies of >90%.  Regarding course modules, there is currently great interest in the ML / hardware communities in sacrificing classification accuracy (i.e., tolerating a 95% classification rate in lieu of 96% depending on the application) for substantial reductions in program run-time, network complexity, and energy.  The teacher planned to leverage different versions of his CNN model in thermal imaging labs to explore these tradeoffs with his students. 

As another example, two RET participants were interested in research related to physics-inspired computing models as they viewed this project as a way to engage HS students with respect to physics standards associated with harmonics, etc. (for which students may not see immediate applications). ND mentors crafted a project regarding the use of coupled oscillators for graph coloring.

Over 40% of the RET participants in our initial program served school districts where the majority of the student body is under-represented minorities. These districts comprise 56% of the student population in our recruiting area.  Subsequent RET cohorts had a high representation of female teachers.

RET modules are posted online and were submitted to national portals.  Modules encompass more than a single assignment and are a collection of materials that provide “deep dives” into a given topic. Modules are associated with a project topic. There is a short description about project activities, and a link to a .zip file that contains (1) a template that addresses how modules address specific state standards, (2) a presentation on a teacher’s work, and (3) classroom activities, assignments, etc.

RET participants worked to establish a Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) chapter for northern Indiana. Ultimately after compiling an application for a local chapter, one participant was approached by representatives of the state’s only existing chapter (in Indianapolis) to help create regional chapter “hubs” throughout the state, and now currently overseas the northern Indiana hub. RET participants are working to build community among local teachers who are interested in CS.

In the last iteration of the site, a small number of elementary school teachers were hosted to build bridges to work at the high school level. Notably, 2 of the 3 Indiana PAEMST nominees for 2021 participated in this RET site.
